info.game_comments:
2003 College Championship final game 1.
From Yale University.

(1, 1).clue: This Union General's troops averaged 12-15 miles a day on their 1864 march to Savannah

(2, 1).clue: If you want to get on his "Late Show", have Rover start practicing a stupid pet trick

(3, 1).clue: This African bird has long, powerful legs & a stride of 15 feet

(5, 1).clue: Army ROTC produces 75% of these, represented by the second letter in ROTC

(6, 1).clue: Sitting on the ocean floor with the Titanic are 500 cases of Bass this that went down with the ship

(1, 2).clue: This state was in the Confederacy, but its western region remained loyal to the Union & formed a new state in 1863

(2, 2).clue: Bits on this late night comedian's show have included "If They Mated" & "Triumph the Insult Comic Dog"

(3, 2).clue: Animal trainer Clyde Beatty was saved from an attacking tiger when Nero, this type of animal, intervened

(4, 2).clue: 18th century religious sect that shares its name with these

(5, 2).clue: As well as leadership, ROTC teaches this "ship" that you learn with a rifle in your hands

(6, 2).clue: It's the truth; this caustic chemical may be sodium hydroxide

(1, 3).clue: It was the first Union fort captured by Confederate forces

(2, 3).clue: Jon Stewart, seen here, hosts this Emmy-winning late night show

(3, 3).clue: As in reindeer, both the male & female have antlers in this North American deer, the "nomad of the north"

(4, 3).clue: Words illustrated here, forwards and backwards

(5, 3).clue: If you get an Army ROTC scholarship, you're committed to serve, either on active duty or in this group

(6, 3).clue: In crosswords, you may come across this 3-letter word for a meadow

(1, 4).clue: An 1860s song tells the story of "The Drummer Boy of" this battle site, also called Pittsburg Landing

(2, 4).clue: Cool guitar-playing Kevin Eubanks is a comic foil for this late night host

(3, 4).clue: This bear may also be called a silvertip because of the white hairs growing in its brown coat

(4, 4).clue: Term for a non-dairy substitute, or the object seen here that holds the real thing

(5, 4).clue: In 1991 Gordon Sullivan was Army Chief of Staff; his boss was fellow ROTC man Colin Powell, in this post
(5, 4).correct response: Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff

(6, 4).clue: When said twice, it's a lemur in Madagascar or an affirmative to a captain

(1, 5).clue: 5 days after this bloody Maryland battle, Lincoln issued his preliminary Emancipation Proclamation

(2, 5).clue: This late night news program originated in 1979 as a nightly report on the hostage crisis in Iran

(3, 5).clue: The unau is the 2-toed species of this South American animal; the ai is the 3-toed species

(4, 5).clue: What CL Grigg made in 1929 with the items seen here is known as this drink brand today

(5, 5).clue: Students in Navy ROTC, first launched at Yale & 5 other schools, are called these

(6, 5).clue: It's a short poem that's sung; Scott wrote one "of the Last Minstrel"

(1, 1).clue: This German philosopher & writing partner of Engels often visited the British Museum when he lived nearby

(2, 1).clue: Her debut solo album "Dangerously in Love" & the single "Crazy in Love" both topped the charts in 2003

(3, 1).clue: (Video of Cheryl on an exercise bench.) It's the noisy name for this exercise, with a smaller range of motion than regular sit-ups

(4, 1).clue: This "Song of Hiawatha" poet was Bowdoin College's first Professor of Modern Languages

(5, 1).clue: One of Mexico's most popular resorts, Cancun is on the Caribbean coast of this peninsula

(6, 1).clue: From the French for "to cut", it's something you cut out & use at the grocery store

(1, 2).clue: Ruling only from 475-476 A.D., Romulus Augustulus is considered by many to have been the last of these

(2, 2).clue: Sheryl Crow sang, "I got no one who will bring me a big umbrella, so I'm watching" this cable TV network

(3, 2).clue: 3 ounces of cooked chicken liver gives 40% of the daily value of the heme type of this mineral

(4, 2).clue: M.I.T. Professor & Nobel Prize winner John Nash inspired this Oscar-winning movie

(5, 2).clue: On February 24 stand up & celebrate Dia de la Bandera, Mexico's equivalent of this June 14th holiday

(6, 2).clue: It's from Norwegian that we get the word ski & this term for a skiing race over a zigzag course

(1, 3).clue: Edward VI became the King of England in 1547 when this King died

(2, 3).clue: A No. 1 album from 2002 was titled "P. Diddy & Bad Boy Records Present ... We Invented" this

(3, 3).clue: (Video of Cheryl fencing.) It's this position in fencing, or what I'm tempted to say to my opponent

(4, 3).clue: Brandeis Sociology Professor Morrie Schwartz is the title teacher in this bestseller by Mitch Albom

(5, 3).clue: Catering to tourists, one of Cancun's major newspapers is the Herald of this U.S. city, about 350 miles north

(6, 3).clue: It should hit you like lightning that this day of the week is named for the Norse god of thunder

(1, 4).clue: In the name of peace, this heroic Egyptian President flew to Jerusalem on Nov. 19, 1977

(2, 4).clue: 3-letter name for the confessional genre of bands like Bright Eyes & Dashboard Confessional

(3, 4).clue: Ann Wigmore popularized the notion that this vegetation seen here has healing power

(4, 4).clue: While he's big on Shakespeare, this literary critic & longtime Yale Professor admits he's no Harry Potter fan

(5, 4).clue: Just a drive away, Tulum & Chichen Itza are famous for their ruins of this Indian people

(6, 4).clue: If you roomed there as a freshman you might know that it's from the Latin for "sleeping place"

(1, 5).clue: The 2000 Mexican elections ended 71 years of rule by the party known by this 3-letter acronym

(2, 5).clue: The documentary "I Am Trying to Break Your Heart" chronicled this band's "Yankee Hotel Foxtrot" CD

(3, 5).clue: If you're 5'10" & weigh 150 pounds, your BMI, short for this, is a normal 21.5

(4, 5).clue: In 1938 he left the University of Rome, stopped in Sweden to pick up his Nobel Physics Prize, then moved to America

(5, 5).clue: Public beaches include Playa Tortuga, or Turtle Beach, & Playa Langosta, this beach

(6, 5).clue: From the Greek for "crooked", this condition often results in an s-shaped curvature of the spine

(0, 0).clue: A European city founded in 1703 has at different times been named for these 2 people born 1,800 years apart
